author: Mariam Abdullahi
title: Emir Sanusi Shares Insights on Reinstatement, Emphasizes Divine Will
text:
Reflecting on his recent reinstatement, Emir Muhammadu Sanusi of Kano emphasized the acceptance of God’s will without questioning it.
In a sermon delivered during Friday prayers at the Kofar Kudu Central Mosque in Kano, Emir Sanusi encouraged people to recognize that all occurrences are part of God’s plan.
Sanusi stressed the significance of embracing Allah’s decisions wholeheartedly, emphasizing that it is not for humans to question God’s divine reasoning.
He expressed, “Gratitude is essential in both favorable and adverse circumstances. Understanding that our experiences are predetermined by God is crucial, and we should be content with His choices for us.”
Emphasizing the importance of supplications during the upcoming Zhul Hijja period, Emir Sanusi highlighted the benefits of observing religious practices during these days.
The reinstatement of Emir Sanusi by Governor Abba Yusuf of Kano State resulted in the removal of Aminu Ado Bayero from the throne last week.
This decision came after the Kano State House of Assembly repealed the Emirate Law, which had divided the Kano Emirate into five separate emirates.
The legislative action not only annulled the five emirates but also led to the restoration of Emir Sanusi to his position.

author: La Stampa
title: Parco eolico Monte Chiappa, i sindaci alzano le barricate - La Stampa
text:
Stop al progetto del parco eolico Monte Chiappa: il sindaco di Andora Mauro Demichelis e i primi cittadini di altri sette comuni hanno inviato una lettera a Regione Liguria e Provincia di Imperia per chiedere il blocco dell’iniziativa. «Riteniamo che i vantaggi prospettati, se rapportati alle conseguenze, non siano convenienti per la nostra realtà», si legge nella lettera indirizzata al presidente della Regione Marco Bucci e al presidente della Provincia Claudio Scajola. «Riteniamo di doverci esprimere come una singola voce rappresentativa di esigenze comuni, così come avvenuto per il Cpr a Diano Castello o per il problema dei rifiuti - scrivono i sindaci - il problema di un singolo comune ha ricadute sull'intero sistema dei territori limitrofi». A firmare la lettera, oltre al primo cittadino di Andora, i sindaci di Cervo, Diano Arentino, Diano Castello, Diano Marina, Diano San Pietro, San Bartolomeo al Mare e Villa Faraldi. «Non ci sono preclusioni verso la produzione di energia alternativa – scrivono -, ma ribadiamo con forza che non può essere fatta compromettendo un'economia solida e storica come quella agricola e olivicola e cementificando zone che sono oggetto di presidio paesaggistico, in aree naturali protette e non idonee».
Il progetto “della discordia” è stato presentato dalla società Tozzi Green di Mantova e ha un valore di oltre 47 milioni di euro. L'impianto si estenderebbe nei comuni di San Bartolomeo al Mare, Villa Faraldi e Andora con sette aerogeneratori da 4,2 Mw ciascuno, per produrre nel complesso 29,4 Mw di energia . Tra le preoccupazioni di amministratori e cittadini, anche le opere infrastrutturali necessarie per il passaggio dei mezzi eccezionali: «Stravolgerebbero la morfologia di territori già fragili, minandone per anni, o per sempre, l'attrattività turistica . Dopo un'attenta analisi dei progetti riteniamo che i vantaggi prospettati, in termini di ricaduta economica per i nostri operatori e di produttività energetica prevista, se rapportati alle conseguenze di anni di cantieri, alla perdita di areali produttivi olivicoli, alle modifiche orografiche richieste per il passaggio di trasporti eccezionali, ai presumibili danni per l'ambiente, di fatto non li rendano vantaggiosi per la nostra realtà» . I sindaci auspicano una soluzione condivisa, rendendosi disponibili a un confronto. Intanto, mercoledì 12 marzo alle 21, nel centro sociale Incontro di San Bartolomeo al Mare riunione pubblica con la cittadinanza.
Leggi i commenti I commenti dei lettori

author: Zachary Stieber
title: Texas Business Owner Who Set His Own Overtime Rules Loses Suit Against Labor Department | The Epoch Times
text: A federal appeals court has upheld the U.S. Department of Labor’s rule mandating automatic overtime pay for workers earning less than a certain amount. The department in 2019 said that workers who make under $684 a week, or $35,568 a year, must be paid overtime for hours beyond 40 a week. The rule raised the figure 50 percent, from $455 a week. The rule was issued under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). Certain employees such as managers, or executive, administrative, professional, and outside sales employees do not need to be paid overtime, provided they make more than the salary level set by the labor department. Robert Mayfield, a small business owner in Texas, sued the agency over the rule. He said the department does not have the authority to set exceptions to not paying overtime based on salary. Mayfield said he paid managers bonuses based on performance rather than overtime pay, and didn’t want to change his system. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit on Sept. 11 ruled against Mayfield. [wrote](https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25136995-fifth-circuit-ruling-in-department-of-labor-case)for the three-judge panel assigned the case. And the agency’s setting of salary level for overtime is within that authority, she said. Elrod pointed to how the department has been adjusting the salary level for the exceptions since shortly after Congress passed the FLSA. “And for those who subscribe to legislative acquiescence, Congress has amended the FLSA numerous times without modifying, foreclosing, or otherwise questioning the Minimum Salary Rule,” she wrote. Mayfield’s lawyers saw the ruling as intrusive. “We are disappointed with the Court’s decision to uphold the minimum salary requirement for exempt employees, a clearly unconstitutional rule that goes beyond the powers Congress granted the Department of Labor,“ Frank Garrison, an attorney with the Pacific Legal Foundation, told The Epoch Times in an email. ”We will continue to fight for our client and the right of small business owners to operate their companies how they see fit, free from government intrusion.” The Department of Labor did not return a request for comment. The agency recently issued an updated rule that mandates overtime pay for workers making less than $58,656 a year if they work more than 40 hours a week. The rule is challenged by several ongoing lawsuits. The Fifth Circuit’s ruling upheld a 2023 decision from U.S. District Judge Robert Pitman, who also found the rule fell within the labor department’s authority. Elrod was joined by U.S. Circuit Judges Cory T. Wilson and Jacques L. Wiener Jr.

author: Humboldt Botanical Garden
title: Humboldt Botanical Garden Orchids Awarded Medal at London Flower Show
text:
EUREKA, Calif., May 30, 2024 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- The “Orchids in the Wild – the Beauty of Nature” display at London’s Chelsea Flower Show, featuring species of orchids from Humboldt Botanical Garden, native to Humboldt County, has been awarded a Silver Gilt Award, the second highest award available. The exhibit has drawn thousands of attendees, including King Charles and Queen Camilla of England.
The Orchid Conservation Educational Exhibit raises global awareness for the conservation and protection of natural orchid habitats, which play a vital role in the health of our ecosystems. Inspired by last year’s success of “Finding the Rare Florida Ghost Orchid” at the 2023 Chelsea Flower Show, a world-renowned Orchid Conservation Team of experts was assembled from across the US, including Dr. Benjamin J. Crain of Humboldt Botanical Garden and the Smithsonian’s North American Orchid Conservation Center (NAOCC). In showcasing a variety of native orchids, the team brings together specialists, horticulturists, and the public in celebration and encouraging efforts to protect these precious plants and their habitats.
For more information about the Show and Awards, visit
https://www.houseandgarden.co.uk/article/chelsea-flower-show-winners-list-2024
Or contact:
Dr. Benjamin J. Crain, Humboldt Botanical Garden,
North American Orchid Conservation Center-
Smithsonian Institution
benjamincrain@hbgf.org
For more information about Humboldt Botanical Garden, located on Eureka’s College of the Redwoods campus and open seven days a week, visit
https://www.globenewswire.com/Tracker?data=nhPMRVRNag85d-7LA0XHjy6iVyz1vLbuV24agJeAUwnZycK65C2doXFeQH-ApCB4-_yQq2AQtx720SELeMioQg==.

author: @mxdwn
title: Marty Friedman Shares Melancholic New Single "A Prayer" - mxdwn Music
text:
Today, innovative guitar visionary Marty Friedman has shared his new single, “A Prayer,” which is from his latest solo album, Drama. The new track is being released as a digital single that includes a “Guitar Karaoke” version of the track as a B-Side. To help explain the song, the guitarist said: “‘A Prayer’ was one of the first songs I wrote for Drama. It is an unapologetic tearjerker and it set the melancholy tone for the entire album. I always wanted to do a full album of wistful songs like this, but only recently have I developed the ability to put together elaborate arrangements like this that sound deceivingly simple and uplifting.”
In other news, Friedman has announced the LIVE DRAMA 2025 US Tour supporting his most recent studio album, Drama, which is out now on Frontiers Music. The tour begins this week on January 24, in Santa Ana and wraps up on February 22, in Los Angeles.
In addition, the artist has a brand-new full autobiography, Dreaming Japanese, that is out now worldwide by Simon and Schuster. It is available at the following vendors: amazon.com, barnesandnoble.com, and
dreamingjapanesebook.com.
topics: Arts, Culture and Entertainment->arts and entertainment

author: George Hancock
title: George Hancock | Brutal July brought monolith sightings
text: July was a brutal weather month. Many regions across our country experienced extreme weather patterns. Wildfires, excessive heat, monsoon rainfall, tornadoes and a strong hurricane ravaged numerous sections of our country. Locally, our weather featured hot and dry conditions. Our rainfall is sparse. We need steady soaking rains. My lawn is brown and cut every two weeks or so, but only the high spots. My hedges are another summer story. Hedges love hot and humid weather. They grow quickly in these conditions, thus needing regular trimming. My July morning runs featured a disturbing sight. Many leaves are withered, changing color and dropping due to our extended dry weather. Running past these July leaves produces a chill. It’s too early for falling leaves. A recent July news story has me scanning the roadside for a view of mysterious objects. Apparently for several years, and mostly out west, monolith structures are appearing in the strangest locations. The most recent monolith appeared on a Colorado farm. This monolith was taken down by the landowners due to the crop damage and trash left behind by curious gawkers. These monoliths attract huge crowds, creating numerous issues for the land owners. Consequently, this monolith was removed. The landowner used a large excavator to remove this nine-foot-tall, four-foot-wide and eight-inch-deep monolith. The land owner said he’s storing the monolith. There was no mention of the monolith’s weight. There were numerous monolith sightings out in the western United States. These structures appear, creating news stories. So I scan my surroundings, looking for the first Greater Johnstown monolith. Well, it could happen. Another July news story created a “Wow!” on my morning run. It seems that every July 1, retired baseball player Bobby Bonilla receives a $1.19 million check from his former team, the New York Mets. This is a great example of astute and savvy financial planning. Bonilla hasn’t played in 20 years. These guaranteed payments are received every year until 2035. Another area along my running routes made the July news. Back in 1975, 74 acres or so on Schoolhouse Road in Richland Township was sold by the University of Pittsburgh at Johnstown to the MetLife Insurance Co. I ran by, watching that building and grounds undergoing construction and landscaping. Eventually, I ran past the employees driving to work. The MetLife parking lot became my shortcut to the Pitt-Johnstown cross country course. Now, this old MetLife building and grounds are being sold back to Pitt-Johnstown. The rezoning process is underway. Just what will Pitt-Johns-town do with that building and grounds? Although I never had any issues running up and down Schoolhouse Road, this area’s unique geographic location created winter driving issues for many MetLife employees. The wide-open old farm fields surrounding the Greater Johnstown Career and Technology Center and the MetLife building was a driving nightmare for these employees. The winter winds formed huge drifts across Schoolhouse Road. I ran around them, but motorists had to stay on the road. Despite the valiant efforts by the Richland road crews, Mother Nature always won. The end result of these wintry road conditions were numerous complaint letters published in The Tribune Democrat’s letters to the editor section. Another local news story featured a fascinating opportunity. Windber Area School District agreed to purchase the Iron Horse Sports Complex, located in Paint Township. This athletic site is a state-of-the-art sports venue. A key component is the large under-roof practice facility. Windber’s athletic teams and the band can now practice year-round in a dry environment. The Iron Horse purchase by Windber was a wise decision. The student and public benefits are enormous. Yet many voiced their opposition to this purchase. Using our recreational opportunities is key to a healthy life. We end on an incredible note. Kaylee Frederick, a 19-year-old Pitt-Johnstown student, recently completed her second Death Valley Badwater 135 run. This 135-mile race begins at the Badwater Basin and finished at the Mount Whitney portal. Ninety-seven runners began this race, but only 79 finished the course. Frederick completed the grueling nonstop course in 36:13:31. She cut four hours off her 2023 finishing time. Well done, Kaylee Frederick! George A. Hancock is a local runner and writer.
